fields.description:
We have done some debugging to try to make sense of what we are seeing. I will do my best to describe:

We used the json RestAPI to create a new review and add reviewers. 
- this seems to be somewhat instant ( as in we receive the response and the review is visable on the web UI )
- however the email about the newly created review takes 5-7 minutes before it hits the smtp server configured in the administration settings.

If we use the "Send a test email" it shows up almost instantly on the smtp server.  

We don't understand the delay? why would sending a mail to reviewers not be instant like the "test" email?

NOTE: we used the same users email for test email and for reviewer
fields.summary: Crucible is slow to send out emails about reviews

fields.description:
*Steps to reproduce*
# As reviewer A create a review with 2 reviewers, A and B, and start it
# Open review as reviewer B in different browser and open review activity stream
# As reviewer A mark review as complete

*Expected behavior*
Entry "Reviewer A completed the review" should be shown in review activity stream

*Current behavior*
It isn't
fields.summary: Review complete/uncomplete is not shown in review activity stream

fields.description:
We have a project that is rather large and contains ~140 repositories. When opening a review, I can usually add content just fine (e.g. by revision). However in this case, when choosing to add a branch, Crucible just crashes. 

I get an exception "No such repository''". We have other projects that work just fine. 

Not sure how I can gather more information so that this can be solved, so please tell me if there is some extra information I can provide.

The version in use is:3.8.0 Build:20150427140019 2015-04-27
fields.summary: Crucible crashes when choosing branches in a review

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
- One JIRA Ticket has one code review in Crucible.
- All commits attached to the JIRA ticket are included in this code review
- It should be easy to sync additional commits to the existing code review from the same ticket

h3. Suggested Solution
Be able to automatically add any additional commits that are added to a JIRA ticket where a review has been created from.
 
h3. Workaround 

# Create a branch review, then by default, all new commits made to a branch will be added to that review. A common workflow is to create a feature branch for a JIRA issue, and make all commits there.
# Use smart commits to add the new commit to an existing review. For example, adding +review CR-123 would add this commit to the CR-123 review.
fields.summary: Add the ability to sync additional commits to an existing open code review from the same JIRA ticket

fields.summary: Anchoring patch to the repository might end up with the exception

fields.description:
HTR:
# create a patch review with two iterations
# move the revision slider, note the 'crossed anchor' icon popping up when you move the from revision
# add a reviewer, start the review
# as the reviewer complete the review
# add another patch revision
# as the reviewer visit the review
# note that the 'lock' icon is now displayed for the files in the patch that you've previously reviewed, and that the content shown is incorrect

Both are these are caused by incorrectly determining whether the patch is anchored (on page-load time, and on slider-move) - the check is done on the subsequent revisions, which aren't anchored in our model. Getting that check wrong causes the icons to be wrong, but also if the check is done at load time (as it is when revisiting a previously reviewed revision), it causes the 'lock' icon to be shown and the content of the files to not be rendered properly.
fields.summary: Files incorrectly marked as not anchored in iterative patch reviews

fields.description:
Creating a review with 2 documents (.docx & .pdf), the gutter renderer displays garbage in renderer when clicking on the pdf file.

Steps to reproduce:
1. create a review with a docx file and a pdf file
2. start the review
3. click the pdf file

> you see the spinner and the content of the pdf file gets rendered

fields.description:
h2. Add branch option for crucible.py script

Add branch option for crucible.py (the "anchorPath" attribute in JSON request, like the "anchorRepository"), which would allow user to manually specify the branch to anchor to. A similar option is available when anchoring a patch via UI. Reasons to add this option are the following:

h3. Anchoring timeouts

When path is not provided, Crucible has to perform more lookups to match the paths from incoming patch to repository paths to identify the best anchor for the patch. This is time-limited operation. If the operation is taking more time, the crucible.py fails with an error:

{noformat}
Error: Failed to anchor the patch to repository XXX, please check that the repository is the correct one
{noformat}

h3. Inaccurate branch selection

Crucible selects a branch to anchor to based on a number of matching files - it picks the branch which has the highest number of paths matching paths from the patch file. In case there are two or more branches matching the same number of paths, a branch with the most recent changes is selected. It can happen that a newer branch is not the one, from which a patch has been created.
fields.summary: Add -b/--branch option to crucible.py (for the "anchorPath" REST parameter)

fields.description:
h4. Steps/Settings to reproduce:
* Permission Scheme with Create set to "All logged in users: true"
* Project "Allowed review participants" set to a certain group
* Create a new review as user that is _not_ contained in said group
* "Edit Details" in review
* Add a reviewer that is _not_ contained in said group
* Click "Done"
=> added user is missing

----
h4. Expected behaviour
When trying to add an user that isn't in the "Allowed review participants" for this project, the user shouldn't be added and an error message of some sort should be displayed instead.
fields.summary: Permission mismatch issues

fields.description:
We use a Jira instance for authentication in Crucible. In a project in Crucible, a group that was synced from Jira has been selected as "Allowed review participants".
This group has been renamed (in Jira), so it would not show up in the configuration page under "Allowed review participants" any more.

However, the permissions still were active because no review participants could be added to reviews (although one would think that it was possible because the configuration page says "Leave blank to let all users access this project" and at least lt _looked_ blank).

The fix was to add the group again with the new name.
fields.summary: [Crowd/Jira] Hidden permission after renaming of group

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Creating a JIRA Issue from a comment in a Crucible review creates an Issue Link in the corresponding JIRA issue, however when the Crucible Project Key is altered the changes are not updated in JIRA.

h3. Environment

Tested with JIRA 6.3 and FishEye 3.8.1 using OAuth Application Links.


h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a JIRA issue from a comment in a Crucible Review: 
!Screen Shot 2015-10-28 at 10.22.31.png|thumbnail! 
# This then adds an Issue link in the newly created JIRA issue: 
!Screen Shot 2015-10-28 at 10.27.48.png|thumbnail!
# Change the project Key of the Crucible project: 
!Screen Shot 2015-10-28 at 10.31.45.png|thumbnail!
# The change is not reflected in the Issue Link: 
!Screen Shot 2015-10-28 at 10.34.12.png|thumbnail!

h3. Expected Results

The Issue link is not updated to reflect the changes to the Project name in Crucible

The Issue Link still holds the old Crucible Project key

fields.description: When I try this option on a review I am the moderator on I get "Review and revision comments hidden. Please visit review."  I am not sure why this is popping up as I have view permissions on the review and I haven't run into any access problems elsewhere.  Is there a setting somewhere that I am missing?  Thanks!
fields.summary: Permission Issues with "Download Review as Text"?

fields.description:
When a user closes a review or mark it as complete, she has the option of also clicking the "Log work" button.  In any organization, some users will press the button every time, some will press it half the time, and some will never press it.  I personally stopped pressing it long ago.

The only way to get good metrics out of that feature is to train users to press the button every time.  So, why not just get rid of the button and automatically log the work every time?

If there's really a use case for not pressing the button, create a "don't log work" opt-out option. I suspect that there is no such use case, however.  It would be a bit like providing an option for leaving the cover sheet off a TPS report.
fields.summary: Crucible "Log work" UX guarantees bad metrics

fields.description:
See CRUC-7466 for original issue, I was able to reproduce the problem locally on 3.10.0 version:
 * define site URL in your instance, e.g. http://fisheye.full.qualified.domain.name/
 * ensure short name is resolved in your DNS (or /etc/hosts file), e.g. fisheye to same address
 * you should be able to login to http://fisheye/ and load particular review (e.g. http://fisheye/cru/TEST-751) without being redirected to http://fisheye.full.qualified.domain.name/
 * but once you click "Edit details" on review page you would get "The server is not responding" error.  This is because AJAX call {{POST /json/cru/TEST-751/edit-details}} gets back empty 302 response with location header: {{Location:https://fisheye.full.qualified.domain.name/cru/TEST-751/edit-details/my-repo/}} which is not being followed

h2. Workaround
use the configured site URL always when using Crucible, restrain from using short URLs
fields.summary: Crucible is inconsistent with redirects causing some Ajax to fail

fields.description:
As Piotr Swiecicki suggested in https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/31676185/answers/31676658, I am filling this enhancement request to make Crucible aware of multiple fisheye repositories defined on the same SVN server.

We have a large SVN server, we created few repositories in fisheye to the few SVN folders that are useful. When someone checks in a single commit on multiple repositories with a smart commits tag (+review ST), Crucible creates 2 reviews when one is warranted.
fields.summary: Duplicate smart commit reviews created from a single commit over multiple fisheye repositories

   -l, --list            list the contents of this backup and exit
   -q, --quiet           suppress output

fields.description:
The logic that detects whether we should use combined diff for SVN repo or not in case of "mixed" content (in combination with massive files) is not correct and can lead to out of memory.

{quote}The reason the heuristic fails for this commit seems to be it's a tag creation commit (which would usually steer towards making a file-by-file diff), mixed in with a lot of modification (which usually indicates a combined diff is more worthwhile). {quote}

fields.description:
h3. Steps to reproduce:

# Click 'Complete' on somebody's review
# Click on the jira assigned to the review
# Click 'More'

h3. Workaround
Follow this procedure to add it natively to your Crucible instance until the change gets pushed in a new version:
# Open Crucible installation folder
# Locate file {{/content/static/nymhro/2static/style/concat.crucible-css.a07db6cf1f589dc8bcc9349604564a7e.cache.css}}
(!)  {{nymhro}} folder and {{a07db6cf1f589dc8bcc9349604564a7e}} might be different in your server but you should have only one folder in {{static}}  and only one file starting with {{concat.crucible-css}}.
# Open the file and add:
{code}
#jira-more-transitions {z-index:999999!important}
{code}
at the end of it.
# Remove  {{/content/static/nymhro/2static/style/concat.crucible-css.a07db6cf1f589dc8bcc9349604564a7e.cache.css.gz}}
(!) Note this is a gz file named like the css you just modified.
# Gzip the file you modified using:
{code}
gzip /content/static/nymhro/2static/style/concat.crucible-css.a07db6cf1f589dc8bcc9349604564a7e.cache.css
{code}
# Navigate to a revision being sure you are using a private browsing mode to be sure you load all the CSS from scratch and not from browser cache.
# Check the HTML source to find the directive importing {{content/static/nymhro/2static/style/concat.crucible-css.a07db6cf1f589dc8bcc9349604564a7e.cache.css}} and open it
# Check if the last line contains the change you made
# Finally check if this solves your issue.
fields.summary: 'More' button on jira dialog on review completion has no action

fields.description:
I would like it if crucible would allow me to filter by multiple reviewers (creator, moderators, authors). The organization I am with has multiple large teams that use the same crucible instance, and my team is divided into three smaller project teams. During our scrum I like to filter down the code reviews that are overdue for my group. This wasn't a problem until I allowed others to lead projects within my group and since they are the leads I am no longer on those code reviews (previously I was on every code review). My old query just found code reviewers where I was a reviewer. Now that I am not on all the code reviews I have to have a query per project lead. I would like to have just one query that will show me all overdue code reviews.

Example of what I have (3 queries)
http://xyz.com/viewer/cru/?filter=custom&project=MyOrg&reviewer=Josh&author=Josh&orRoles=true&state=Review
http://xyz.com/viewer/cru/?filter=custom&project=MyOrg&reviewer=Nick&author=Nick&orRoles=true&state=Review
http://xyz.com/viewer/cru/?filter=custom&project=MyOrg&reviewer=Mike&author=Mike&orRoles=true&state=Review

What I would like to do
http://xyz.com/viewer/cru/?filter=custom&project=MyOrg&reviewer=Josh,Nick,Michael&author=Josh,Nick,Michael&orRoles=true&state=Review

I don't believe the crucible rest APIs allow this. 
What I have done:
- Read the API documentation online
- Searched the JIRA crucible queue
- Tried my new modified query
- Asked within my organization
fields.summary: Allow multiple reviewers when filtering reviews on the review dashboard

fields.description:
h3. Summary
# Symptom 1: After the upgrade, for an existing review screen, it shows the files, but when a file is clicked, it doesn't show the source for the file. Trying to summarise or close the review will also fail.
# Symptom 2: When creating a new review, the wizard does not show the screen for picking the reviewers. It skips that screen and instead creates the review in a draft mode.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a directory in your SVN repository with name having an apostrophe. 
# Add a file under that directory and checkin the directory and file into SVN. 
# Create a review for this changeset

h3. Expected Results
The Review can be edited and created successfully.

h3. Actual Results
When creating review for a changeset, the edit review dialog doesn't show and JS errors are reported on this action: 
!frx-with-apos.png|thumbnail!

Edit action fails with error:
{noformat}
URL: /foo/json/cru/edit-details
404: Not Found
{noformat} 

The exception reported is:
{noformat}
2015-09-03 08:49:06,806 ERROR [qtp1855610584-6946 ] com.atlassian.plugins.rest.common.error.jersey.ThrowableExceptionMapper ThrowableExceptionMapper-toResponse - Uncaught exception thrown by REST service: 'undefined' is an invalid Review PermaId
com.cenqua.crucible.model.PermaIdFormatException: 'undefined' is an invalid Review PermaId
at com.cenqua.crucible.model.managers.impl.DefaultReviewManager.getReviewByPermaId(DefaultReviewManager.java:518)
at com.atlassian.crucible.spi.impl.DefaultReviewService.getRequiredReview(DefaultReviewService.java:592)
at com.atlassian.crucible.spi.impl.DefaultReviewService.getReviewData(DefaultReviewService.java:1132)
at com.atlassian.crucible.spi.impl.DefaultReviewService.getReview(DefaultReviewService.java:1122)
{noformat}
 
h3. Workaround
[Exclude|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/include-exclude-paths-298976903.html#IncludeExcludepaths-AddinganExclude] the folder paths that contain the apostrophe character.
fields.summary: Crucible review dysfunctional when file path contains apostrophe character

fields.description:
h3. Summary
In Crucible, on the project page, if a repository is the default repository of a project, and it is added under {{FishEye Content}} using {{Use whole repository}}, the repository is listed twice.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Set a repository to the default repository of a project. (i.e. {{testrepo}})
# Add {{testrepo}} in the {{FishEye Content}} settings of the repository, using the {{Use whole repository}} option.
# Visit the project page. {{testrepo}} will be listed twice.

h3. Expected Results
The repository should only be listed once.

h3. Actual Results
The repository is listed twice.

h3.Workaround
Remove the reference to the default repository in the {{FishEye Content}} settings for the repository.
fields.summary: Project Page Lists Repository Twice

fields.description:
Hi,
I've encountered a problem that I have not seen with other code review / diff tools.

Version:3.1.3                Build:20130917011630 2013-09-17

Say I create a review, people make comments and I add an update, so far so good. Then after I upload the new diff, Crucible shows changes that another person has made to the file, that had been made after the creation of my first patch, but had been committed before I created my second patch.

Then this happens:

Reviewer X: Hey you, Crucible shows me that you made this change, which looks wrong as it is not in the scope of your jira.
Me – (after spending some time to figure out what is going on) hey, that actually is not a part of the patch I uploaded.
Reviewer X: oh ok, have a nice day.

Given the new diff does not contain the change, it would be good to filter out diffs that are actually not part of the review, or at least show them as being a change that had been made by another developer.
fields.summary: Reviews sometimes show other users changes

fields.description:
h2. Detail & Workaround
When a user creates a new review and you attempt to add yourself as a reviewer to it, you are permitted to add the user but it does not save.  This blocks the code review from being completed.  Workaround was just to have the original author close the review and the reviewer creates a new one.

h2. Steps to Reproduce
I have a screen cap of this if necessary but it contains proprietary information that I cannot post publicly.
\\
\\
# User 1 creates a new review (from Git repo in this case)
# User 1 sends a link to User 2
# User 2 attempts to add self as reviewer:
## Click link
## Click _Edit Details_
## Type in name of user in _Reviewers_ type-ahead list and click it when it pops up
## Click _Done_
# User 2 clicks _Edit Details_ again to verify
# User 2 is not persisted as a reviewer on the opened issue

h2. Results
h3. Actual
User can add self in _Details_ screen, but clicking _Done_ does not appear to commit the change.
h3. Expected
User can add self in _Details_ screen and clicking _Done_ either produces an error stating that the save failed for some reason or the change is actually saved.
fields.summary: unable to add reviewer to opened review

fields.description:
h2. Overview
The review workflow built into Crucible is useful, particularly for small, hands-on teams.  However the simplicity of the flow leads to confusion as to who is responsible for what during the review process.

h2. Background
I've recently been involved in conversations in search of a new revision control system, branching structure, CI and code review tools.  Participants of the conversation quickly pointed out that while Crucible works well for code reviews, it is not well integrated into the CI process or development workflow.  For example, the back and forth between reviewers and developers is largely an off-line process, requreing manual coordination.  Reading Atlassian's documentation on Crucible workflows it seems that there is no option to improve review workflows.  Additionally, I see a common theme in the commentary about confusion or disappointment in the workflow.

https://confluence.atlassian.com/crucible/the-crucible-workflow-298977485.html
https://confluence.atlassian.com/crucible/defining-your-workflow-298977486.html

Unfortunately it seems that for this reason, Crucible is loosing out over tooling such as Gerrit (which by many accounts offers a less desirable code review experience).

h2. Details
Specifically, I am looking for the ability to "kick back" a review to a developer, which both:
# Notifies the developer that action is required
# Marks the review, showing the state of the review (action pending) and who is responsible

Without this we find that reviews are often left floating with unclear actions needed (or not).  

Additionally, I don't think there is a way for results of a code review to drive or trigger action.  In other words, a review can only be moved to the Closed status, without any indication as to whether the review is acceptable or not.  This feature could enable a CI tool to detain a commit in the same way it might if unit tests fail.
fields.summary: Consider adding functionality to review workflows

fields.description:
Hi,
We would like to have the ability to publish a branch for review against a master branch in another repository in GIT.

This is in reference with issue CRC-8619.

We have a team of around 40 developers, which includes junior developers, so for security reason, our current review system requires seperate repositories for each developer. These repositories are cloned from the production repository. All the precommit reviews are published under developers' public repositories.

During code review, the developer's branch is reviewed against the production branch from which it was branched.

For example:
Developer A is working on feature_x.
They will checkout feature_x from the production repository to their public repository.
All commits will be done to branch feature_x in the developer's public repository.
During code review, the reviewer will compare the feature_x in developer's public repository against production/feature_x.

** git diff production/feature_x developer/feature_x

Please refer to the image attached for clarification.

We have adapted to this review process for a long time and we would like to keep working this way, but this functionality is currently not supported in Crucible.

The team currently uses other Atlassian products (e.g. Jira, Confluence), and we would like to use Crucible for our code reviews.

Regards,

Saju Thomas & Amani Mbara
Senior Software Engineers
MultiChoice Africa.
fields.summary: Support to publish a review against a branch in another repository in GIT
